intro: Lepidium campestre subsp. pratense, commonly known as field peppergrass, is a low-growing annual herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically reaches heights of 10–30 cm and features slender, branching stems covered with small, glandular hairs. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers in clusters, which are followed by cylindrical, segmented fruits called siliques. Its leaves are alternate, linear to lanceolate, and often have a slightly hairy texture. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in grasslands, roadsides, and agricultural fields.
